questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents with gradually worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. He has a history of tuberculosis treated 10 years ago. Physical examination reveals elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP) that rises paradoxically with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: constrictive pericarditis, a condition where the pericardium, the sac surrounding the heart, becomes thickened and constricted, impeding normal heart function. The key clinical finding supporting the diagnosis is the Kussmaul sign- a paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration . The patient's history of tuberculosis further supports the diagnosis, as tuberculosis can lead to pericardial inflammation and subsequent constriction. constrictive pericarditis" data-author="" data-hash="8650" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" height="482" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/694NK32BXWkOSziTvHqd1744296814.png" width="482" /> Kussmaul’s Sign : Abnormal rise or failure of JVP to decrease with inspiration. Classically seen in conditions like constrictive pericarditis. Also seen in pulmonary embolism, RV infarction, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and advanced systolic heart failure. While other options like restrictive cardiomyopathy, right ventricular infarction, and pulmonary embolism can also present with the Kussmaul sign, they are less likely to occur and to be involved with tuberculosis. (Options A, B & C ruled out) Wave/ Descent Refers Clinical Significance a Wave Atrial contraction (right atrium), follows the P wave on ECG and precedes S1 Prominent in RV compliance issues Early Prominent- Tricuspid stenosis Late Prominent- Mitral stenosis Absent in atrial fibrillation Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia. x Descent Fall in right atrial pressure post-a wave, reflecting atrial relaxation Dominant in normal jugular venous pulses. Prominent- Cardiac tamponade and constrictive pericarditis Absent- Tricuspid Regurgitation c Wave Occurs during ventricular systole, tricuspid valve bulges into the right atrium Seen in the ventricular systole Can coincide with a carotid pulse. v Wave Passive Atrial filling after ventricular systole follows S2 Prominent in tricuspid regurgitation (TR) In severe TR, the C wave may merge with the V wave, creating a " ventricularized " waveform—a giant V or CV wave . y Descent Fall in right atrial pressure after tricuspid valve opening Absent in pericardial tamponade Prominent in constrictive pericarditis or severe TR. Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th Edition, Page 126, 127, 128. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1817 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9271481/

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct about grades of murmurs?

options.A: Grade 1 murmur is very loud and audible even without a stethoscope
options.B: Grade 2 murmur is faint but audible with a stethoscope.
options.C: Grade 4 murmur has a loud intensity without thrill.
options.D: Grade 6 murmur is very faint and heard with difficulty.

questions.explanation: with difficulty. Grade 2 Faint but audible with a stethoscope. Grade 3 Moderately loud, easily audible. Grade 4 Loud, with a palpable thrill. Grade 5 Very loud, with a palpable thrill, heard with the edge of the stethoscope. Grade 6 Extremely loud, audible without a stethoscope, with a palpable thrill. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 281, 282, 284.

questions.question: Match the Following Murmurs to Their Characteristics or Associated Conditions Murmurs Characteristics or Associated Conditions 1. Mitral Stenosis A. High-pitched, crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. 2. Aortic Stenosis B. Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, often with a displaced apical impulse. 3. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) C. Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard along the left sternal border. 4. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy D. "Machine-like" continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area. 5. Mitral Regurgitation E. Loud S1, opening snap, and low-pitched diastolic murmur heard best at the apex. 6. Aortic Regurgitation F. Systolic ejection murmur, often with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the right upper sternal border, radiating to the carotids.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) 1 - E, 2 - F, 3 - A, 4 - D, 5 - C, 6 - B Explanation: Mitral Stenosis Low-pitched diastolic murmur with opening snap, best at the apex. Accentuated by exercise or Valsalva's maneuver. Aortic Stenosis Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids Patent Ductus Arteriosus A continuous, machine-like murmur, heard at the left infraclavicular area Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Harsh systolic murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern Mitral Regurgitation Holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla Aortic Regurgitation Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border Graham Steell Murmur Early diastolic decrescendo murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation, heard best at the left upper sternal border. Austin Flint Murmur Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur due to severe aortic regurgitation causing turbulent flow in the left ventricle. Carvallo's Sign Increased intensity of a tricuspid regurgitation murmur with inspiration, heard along the left lower sternal border. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 281-286, 1821-1823, 1969

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with exertional chest pain and dyspnea. On physical examination, you note a harsh mid systolic murmur that is loudest at the left sternal border and increases in intensity with the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: increases with Valsalva due to dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction becoming more pronounced as preload decreases. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): It is characterized by the thickening of the heart muscle, specifically the left ventricle, without other underlying causes like high blood pressure or aortic valve disease. Clinical Presentation: The condition is often associated with a mid systolic murmur , which is typically most pronounced at the left sternal border or near the heart's apex . This murmur results from dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction and mitral regurgitation (MR). Murmur intensity increases with maneuvers that decrease preload or afterload (like standing or the Valsalva maneuver) and decreases with maneuvers that increase preload or afterload (like squatting or volume administration) . Diagnosis : Echocardiography is a key diagnostic tool for HCM. Condition Murmur Characteristics Aortic Stenosis (AS) (Option B ruled out) Systolic murmur is loudest to the right of the sternum, radiating to the neck. The intensity remains constant with maneuvers (unlike HCM). Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP) Late systolic murmur is best heard at the apex. Typically preceded by a non-ejection click, and intensity and duration increases with maneuvers that decrease ventricular volume. Pulmonic Stenosis (PS) (Option C ruled out) Systolic murmur is best heard in the second and third intercostal spaces. Intensity increases with severity but decreases with maneuvers that decrease pulmonary blood flow. Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) (Option D ruled out) Midsystolic murmur is best heard at the left sternal border, due to increased pulmonary blood flow. Typically has fixed splitting of the second heart sound. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 281- 286, 1821-1823, 1969

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a loud, high-pitched murmur heard best at the apex of the heart, radiating to the axilla. The intensity of the murmur does not change with inspiration. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: at the apex of the heart and radiates to the axilla. It does not change with inspiration. Rheumatic heart disease is a common cause of chronic MR due to mitral valve damage. Chronic tricuspid regurgitation (Option B) becomes louder on inspiration. Best heard in the lower left sternal edge. Aortic Stenosis (Option C) presents with ejection systolic murmur. Besy heard in the right second intercostal space, may radiate to the carotid arteries. Acute mitral Regurgitation (Option D) causes early murmur due to rapid rise in left atrial pressure. Best heard in the apex, may radiate to the axilla. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 279-283

questions.question: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of high blood pressure detected during a routine check-up. On physical examination, the blood pressure is higher in the arms compared to the legs. A continuous murmur is heard over the back, near the left scapula. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: artery, leading to higher blood pressure in the arms than in the legs and a continuous murmur over the back. Coarctation of the Aorta Narrowing occurs where the ductus arteriosus connects to the aorta, distal to the left subclavian artery. Causes elevated blood pressure above the narrowing (upper limbs) and reduced blood pressure below it (legs). Clinical Features Can cause cardiac failure in newborns but may be asymptomatic in older children or adults. Hypertension above narrowing may cause headaches; reduced blood flow below may lead to leg cramps or weakness. Radio-femoral delay. A continuous murmur is typically heard over the back near the left scapula. Additional sound (ejection click) may be heard in the aortic area if a bicuspid aortic valve is present. Collateral circulation develops through periscapular, internal mammary, and intercostal arteries, sometimes causing localized bruits Takayasu arteritis (Option A) is a large-vessel vasculitis that can cause pulse discrepancies and limb claudication, and does not typically present with a continuous murmur or blood pressure gradient between limbs. Atrial septal defect (Option C) causes a fixed split of the second heart sound and a systolic murmur due to increased flow across the pulmonary valve, but it does not cause blood pressure differences between the arms and legs. Aortic dissection (Option D) presents with sudden, severe chest or back pain and may cause unequal blood pressures in the arms and not associated with a continuous murmur. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 284 Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 534

questions.question: In aortic regurgitation, capillary pulsations can be seen in the nail beds. What is this sign called?
questions.explanation: deMusset's sign (Option C ruled out) A head bob occurring with each cardiac cycle Mueller's sign Systolic pulsations of the uvula. Becker's sign Visible pulsations of the retinal arteries and pupils. Quincke's pulses (Option A) Visible Capillary pulsations in the nailbeds after holding the tip of the nail. Duroziez's sign (Option B ruled out) A systolic and diastolic bruit heard when the femoral artery is partially compressed.to and fro murmur Traube's sign A pistol shot murmur (systolic and diastolic sounds) heard over the femoral arteries. Mayne's sign More than a 15 mmHg decrease in DBP with arm elevation from the value obtained with the arm in the standard position. Hill's sign Popliteal cuff systolic pressure exceeding brachial pressure by more than 60 mmHg. Rosenbach's sign Systolic pulsations of the liver. Gerhard's sign Systolic pulsations of the spleen. Austin Flint sign (Option D): It is a low-pitched, mid-diastolic rumbling heart murmur, best heard at the apex, associated with severe aortic regurgitation. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557428/ Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 524-525

questions.question: From the list of ECG findings given below which will not be seen in mitral stenosis?
questions.explanation: (Option A) can be seen in mitral stenosis due to right ventricular hypertrophy secondary to pulmonary hypertension. Bifid P wave (Option B) (also called P mitrale) is a classic sign of left atrial enlargement, commonly seen in mitral stenosis. Atrial fibrillation (Option C) frequently occurs in mitral stenosis due to left atrial dilation and increased pressure. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 519

questions.question: Which of the following schematic represents murmur of mitral stenosis? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Definition Narrowing of the mitral valve, usually due to rheumatic disease, causing obstruction to blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle Symptoms Breathlessness Fatigue Oedema, ascites Palpitation Haemoptysis Cough Chest pain Thromboembolism Systolic murmurs Diastolic murmurs Midsystolic Aortic stenosis Pulmonic stenosis Atrial septal defect HOCM Early diastolic Aortic regurgitation Pulmonic regurgitation Austin-Flint Holosystolic Mitral regurgitation Tricuspid regurgitation VSD Mid/late diastolic Mitral stenosis Tricuspid stenosis Late systolic murmur Mitral valve prolapse Other rare murmurs Patent ductus arteriosus Options B and C have systolic murmur. Option D shows early diastolic murmur.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with fatigue and a rapid, low-volume pulse. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the treatment?
questions.explanation: used for treatment. The X-ray shows diffuse pericardial calcification along the left lateral and inferior wall of the heart. pericarditis radiology" data-author="D'Souza D, Campos A, Worsley C" data-hash="8659" data-license="NA" data-source="https://radiopaedia.org/articles/constrictive-pericarditis" data-tags="April2025" height="448" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/q7HEhAHtqU8SPuZyduzG1744297364.png" width="392" /> Chronic constrictive pericarditis: Clinical Features Fatigue Rapid, low-volume pulse Elevated JVP with rapid y descent Loud early third heart sound (‘pericardial knock’) Kussmaul’s sign ( rise in JVP during inspiration) Hepatomegaly Ascites Peripheral edema Pulsus paradoxus (rare) Investigations Chest X-ray: May show pericardial calcification Echo and cardiac catheterization to differentiate from restrictive cardiomyopathy Management Diuretics: Loop diuretics (Option A) and aldosterone antagonists (e.g., spironolactone) Surgical resection: Diseased pericardium removal, though with high morbidity and variable outcomes Pericardiocentesis

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma lung presents with sudden dyspnoea, tachycardia, and hypotension. Examination reveals elevated JVP and an abnormal drop of 15mm Hg in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. An ECG was performed and is given below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation: Percutaneous pericardiocentesis is the most appropriate next step as the patient shows signs of cardiac tamponade, including hypotension , elevated JVP , pulsus paradoxus (drop in systolic BP >10–15 mmHg on inspiration), and ECG changes, and urgent drainage of the pericardial fluid is required to relieve pressure on the heart and restore cardiac output. Intravenous diuretics (Option A) are not helpful in tamponade, as reducing preload can worsen hypotension and cardiac output. Start vasopressors (Option C) may temporarily support blood pressure but do not address the underlying mechanical compression , and delaying definitive treatment can be fatal. Schedule elective cardiac surgery (Option D) is inappropriate for an emergency like tamponade; pericardiocentesis is the immediate life-saving measure. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th edition, Page 544

questions.question: A 60-year-old man with a history of heart failure presents with worsening edema and jugular venous distention. You observe a steep x and steep y descent in the jugular venous waveform. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation: before the calcified pericardial sac limits the diastole. Wave/ Descent Clinical Significance a Wave Absent in atrial fibrillation Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia. x Descent Absent x descent in tricuspid regurgitation (Option B ruled out) v Wave Prominent in tricuspid regurgitation It may merge with the c wave in severe TR, creating a " ventricularized " waveform . y Descent Blunted in pericardial tamponade (Option C ruled out) Steep in pericardial constriction and severe TR. Acute pericarditis (Option D) without any complication or associated pericardial conditions will have normal JVP waves. Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th Edition, Page 126, 127, 128. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1817

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows an unequal number of P waves and R waves and his jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing is shown below. Which of the following conditions is responsible for this finding?
questions.explanation: seen in complete heart block or AV dissociation, where atrial and ventricular contractions are unsynchronized. This causes intermittent, forceful atrial contractions, resulting in large, visible "a waves" in the JVP. a Wave Occurs due to atrial contraction. Follows P wave on ECG. Precedes S1 Clinical Significance: Prominent in reduced RV compliance Absent in atrial fibrillation (Option A ruled out) Cannon a waves in AV dissociation and ventricular tachycardia. They occur when the right atrium contracts against a closed tricuspid valve, typically seen with AV dissociation. In wide complex tachycardia, cannon ‘a’ waves in the jugular venous waveform suggest a ventricular origin of the rhythm. Tricuspid stenosis (Option C): Tricuspid stenosis causes prominent a waves , but they are not "cannon" waves. Instead, these are consistently elevated due to restricted tricuspid valve flow, not due to AV dissociation. Supraventricular tachycardia (Option D): Supraventricular tachycardia is typically associated with coordinated atrial and ventricular activity, and thus does not cause cannon ‘a’ waves.

questions.question: Loud first heart sound (S1) in mitral stenosis indicates?
questions.explanation: a loud first heart sound. First heart sound (S1): The first heart sound is due to the closing of the AV valves. It occurs at the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction as lub sound. The intensity of S1 is determined by the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve must travel to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval. S1 is loud in rheumatic MS, hyperkinetic circulatory states and short PR interval. Reduced LV compliance (Option A) typically affects diastolic filling but does not directly cause a loud S1; it may even reduce it in some conditions. Severe calcified mitral stenosis (Option C) leads to immobile, stiff valve leaflets , which reduce the intensity of S1, making it soft or absent , not loud. Hypertrophy of the right ventricle (Option D) may be a consequence of pulmonary hypertension due to mitral stenosis, but it does not directly affect the loudness of S1 . Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1819

questions.question: A 70-year-old woman with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy, hypertension, and diabetes presents with worsening shortness of breath and fatigue. On physical examination, you hear both an S3 and an S4 heart sound. Which of the following best explains the presence of both heart sounds in this patient?

options.C: Combined systolic and diastolic heart failure

questions.explanation: An S3 is due to increased ventricular filling pressure and occurs in systolic heart failure, while an S4 arises from atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle, commonly seen in diastolic dysfunction. The patient's history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and multiple comorbidities (hypertension, diabetes) further supports this diagnosis. Atrial fibrillation with mitral stenosis (Option A) : An S4 is absent in atrial fibrillation because atrial contraction is ineffective. Mitral stenosis typically causes a loud S1 and an opening snap, not an S3 or S4. Acute mitral regurgitation (Option B): Acute mitral regurgitation can cause an S3 due to rapid ventricular filling, but an S4 would be uncommon unless there is concurrent diastolic dysfunction, which is less likely in an acute setting. Severe aortic stenosis (Option D): Aortic stenosis can cause an S4 due to the stiff left ventricle. However, an S3 is less likely unless there is concurrent left ventricular failure. Isolated aortic stenosis would not explain both sounds. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 459 Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th Edition, Page 130, 131

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presents with palpitations. On examination, hyperdynamic precordium is noted with soft S1 and pansystolic murmur. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: blood flows back into the left atrium during systole. Sound Timing Mechanisms Characteristics Variable Features First heart sound (S1) Beginning of systole Mitral and tricuspid valve closure Typically single or slightly split Loud in conditions like anemia, pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, mitral stenosis Soft in heart failure, mitral regurgitation Second heart sound (S2) End of systole Aortic and pulmonary valve closure (A2 first, P2 second) Splits during inspiration; single on expiration Fixed wide splitting with atrial septal defect Wide variable splitting with delayed right heart emptying (RBBB) Reversed splitting due to delayed left heart emptying (LBBB) Third heart sound (S3) Early diastole, after S2 Sudden deceleration of blood filling into ventricles Low pitch, often heard as 'gallop' Normal in young people and pregnancy Pathological in heart failure, mitral regurgitation Fourth heart sound (S4) Late diastole, before S1 Atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle Low pitch Present in severe left ventricular hypertrophy Absent in atrial fibrillation Hyperthyroidism (Option A): Hyperthyroidism can cause tachycardia, leading to a louder S1, not a soft S1. Mitral stenosis (Option B): Mitral stenosis typically causes a loud S1 due to the forceful closure of a stiffened mitral valve. Tachycardia (Option D): Rapid heart rate can cause a louder S1, as the mitral valve closes more forcefully during fast cardiac cycles. Reference: Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 24th Edition, Page 459 Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th Edition, Page 130, 131

questions.question: A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and occasional chest discomfort. He mentions that the episodes are sudden in onset and can last for several minutes before resolving spontaneously. His vitals are stable, and physical examination is unremarkable. An ECG of the condition is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome. WPW syndrome is a condition in which an accessory electrical pathway (Bundle of Kent) allows abnormal conduction of impulses from the atria to the ventricles, bypassing the normal AV node, leading to pre-excitation of the ventricles. ECG Findings: Short PR interval (<120 ms) due to rapid conduction through the accessory pathway. Delta wave: A slurred upstroke in the QRS complex, caused by pre-excitation of the ventricles. Seen in V4. Wide QRS complex due to fusion of normal and pre-excitation conduction. Types of Tachyarrhythmias Associated with WPW: Atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): The most common arrhythmia in WPW. Atrial fibrillation (AF): Can be life-threatening in WPW, with very rapid ventricular rates. Atrial Fibrillation (Option A): AF can occur in WPW but does not cause a delta wave and presents with irregular rhythm rather than the specific findings in WPW. Myocardial Infarction (Option C): MI causes ischemic changes on ECG, such as ST elevation or Q waves, but not the delta wave or short PR interval seen in WPW. Atrioventricular Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT) (Option D): A common type of SVT without the delta wave or short PR interval seen in WPW. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554437/

questions.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents due to concerns about his difficulty keeping up with peers during physical activities. Inspection shows a prominent precordium. Auscultation reveals a systolic ejection murmur. What heart sounds will be heard in this case?
questions.explanation: S2 because of increased right heart blood flow, leading to delayed pulmonic valve closure. Atrial Septal Defect: Congenital, low-pressure, left to right shunt. Right ventricle will have volume overloading. Types of ASD: Ostium Secundum (most common), Ostium Primum, Sinus Venosus On auscultation: Wide fixed split S2 sound Chest x-ray: May show enlarged right atrial and right ventricular enlargement and increased pulmonary markings Transthoracic echocardiogram: Gold standard imaging modality, helps to detect size and assess the direction of blood flow. Narrow split S2 (Option A): Seen in conditions with slight delays in valve closure, such as mild left ventricular failure or early aortic stenosis, not typical for ASD. Paradoxical split S2 (Option B): Seen in conditions like left bundle branch block or severe aortic stenosis where A2 is delayed and occurs after P2. Wide split variable S2 (Option D): Seen in conditions like ventricular septal defect (VSD) or right bundle branch block (RBBB), where the split changes with respiration. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535440/

questions.question: A 7-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a history of recurrent respiratory infections and exercise intolerance. On physical examination, a holosystolic murmur is noted at the left lower sternal border, and the child exhibits signs of left-to-right shunting. What is this condition most likely associated with?
questions.explanation: variable S2. Ventricular Septal Defect: Shunt from left ventricle to right ventricle. Types of VSD: Perimembranous, Membranous, Supracristal. On auscultation: Wide variable split second heart sound. ECG: May show left ventricular hypertrophy. Chest x-ray: May show cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Wide Fixed split S2 (Option A) occurs in conditions like atrial septal defect (ASD), where the split remains constant during respiration due to continuous right heart volume overload, which is not seen in VSD. Paradoxical split S2 (Option B) happens when A2 occurs after P2, often due to conditions like HOCM with severe LV obstruction or severe aortic stenosis. It is not typical for VSD. Narrow split S2 (Option C) indicates a delayed closure of the aortic valve but is not characteristic of VSD, where increased right-sided volume typically causes a wider split. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470330/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553135/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea and occasional dizziness. On auscultation, a harsh crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is noted at the left sternal border, which increases with the Valsalva maneuver. There is also evidence of a jerky carotid pulse. Which of the following will be heard on auscultation in this case?
questions.explanation: ventricular outflow tract obstruction. It can delay the closure of the aortic valve (A2). This leads to the paradoxical splitting of S2, where A2 occurs after P2, causing the split to be heard during expiration. HCOM: Clinical Features Symptoms: Dyspnea on exertion , angina , syncope , palpitations . Sudden death during exercise. Auscultation Harsh systolic murmur best heard at the left sternal border . Increases with Valsalva and standing ( ↓ preload). Decreases with squatting ( ↑ preload/afterload). ECG Findings LVH , deep Q waves , and sometimes arrhythmias . May show left atrial enlargement . Echocardiogram Diagnostic test of choice. Shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy (septal thickness >15 mm). S ystolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve. Management First-line: Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., verapamil). Avoid vasodilators , diuretics , and nitrates — they reduce preload and worsen obstruction. ICD indicated in high-risk cases (history of SCD, syncope, family history). Wide split S2 (Option A): This occurs when there is a delayed closure of the pulmonic valve (P2), causing an exaggerated split that increases during inspiration. Common in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) or pulmonic stenosis. Fixed split S2 (Option B): The split remains constant throughout the respiratory cycle, typically seen in atrial septal defect (ASD), due to continuous right heart volume overload. Physiological split S2 (Option D): A normal finding where the split between A2 and P2 increases during inspiration and disappears during expiration due to increased venous return delaying P2. Reference: pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7785055/#:~:text=Physiological%20splitting%20of%20the%20seco nd,increase%20in%20central%20venous%20return. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430788/

questions.question: Narrow split S2 heart sound is heard in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: (aortic component) closer to P2 (pulmonic component). Types of S2 Splitting: Physiological Splitting: Occurs during inspiration when the increased venous return to the right side of the heart delays P2, widening the split between A2 and P2. Normal and disappears during expiration. Wide Splitting: Duration > 30msec. A2 and P2 are widely separated, and the split is exaggerated during inspiration. Causes: Pulmonic stenosis, right bundle branch block (RBBB), atrial septal defect (ASD), mitral regurgitation. Narrow Splitting: Duration < 30msec. A2 and P2 are close together, with less noticeable separation. Causes: Aortic stenosis (Option B) , systemic hypertension. Mitral regurgitation (Option A): In mitral regurgitation, the S2 sound is typically unaffected. However, an S3 sound (due to volume overload) may be heard. Atrial septal defect (ASD) (Option C): In ASD, a wide and fixed split S2 is heard due to increased right-sided volume, which delays the closure of the pulmonic valve (P2). Pulmonary hypertension (Option D): This can lead to a delayed P2, causing a wide split S2, not a narrow split. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557628/ pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC7785055/#:~:text= Physiological%20splitting%20of%20the%20second,increase%20in%20central%20venous%20return.

questions.question: Match the following Condition Type of S2 Splitting 1) Wide Split a) RBBB 2) Paradoxical Splitting b) Mitral regurgitation 3) Fixed Splitting c) LBBB 4) Narrow Split d) Pulmonary artery hypertension e) ASD
questions.explanation: 3)Fixed Splitting ASD 4)Narrowed splitting Pulmonary artery hypertension Aortic and pulmonic valve closure constitutes the second heart sound (S2 ). With normal or physiologic splitting, the A2 –P2 interval increases with inspiration and narrows during expiration resulting in a wide split. Splitting of S2 and associated conditions: Wide Splitting Occurs in conditions like right bundle branch block (RBBB) due to delayed pulmonic valve closure. Seen in severe mitral regurgitation (MR) due to premature closure of the aortic valve- Wide and variable split is seen. Narrow Splitting or Singular S2 Narrow Splitting- E.g. Aortic stenosis or Singular S2 Wide Fixed Splitting The A2-P2 interval is wide and does not change during the respiratory cycle. E.g.- ASD, TAPVC, RVF Reversed or Paradoxical Splitting- P2 before A2 Seen in conditions such as left bundle branch block (LBBB). Right ventricular pacing. Severe aortic stenosis (AS). Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), Acute myocardial ischemia. Loud P2 Considered loud when its intensity exceeds A2 at the base or can be palpated in the proximal main pulmonary artery area. E.g.- Pulmonary arterial hypertension. Decreased Intensity A2 intensity decreases with aortic stenosis (AS) and P2 intensity decreases with pulmonic stenosis (PS), potentially resulting in a single S2. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1819, 1820.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman comes with a history of fever, chest pain, weight loss, and night sweats. During a physical examination of a patient, the physician notes a characteristic sound that persists on breath holding. On further evaluation, she is found to have pericardial effusion on echocardiogram. What is this finding called on auscultation known as?
questions.explanation: friction rub , that is present even when the patient holds his breath. Tuberculous pericarditis is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis . There is a serofibrinous exudate outside the heart which causes inflammation and irritation of the phrenic nerve, causing pain to radiate to the shoulders. Presents with chest pain at rest. On examination: Pericardial friction rub (scratchy sound on auscultation) present even when patient holds his breath. Investigation of choice: CBNAAT or Gene Expert testing of pericardial fluid. Treatment: ATT for 6 months. Opening snap (Option A) is a high pitch sound heard in cases of mitral stenosis, follows S2, occurring in early diastole. Pericardial knock (Option C) also known as pericardial shudder is seen in cases of calcification around the heart in patients after treatment with ATT. Pleural rub (Option D) is best heard in the phase of deep inspiration and disappears on breath holding. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 1992, 2020-2022

questions.question: Which of the following features would raise suspicion for a diagnosis of Carney complex rather than sporadic cardiac myxomas?
questions.explanation: skin lesions (pigmentation), and endocrinal abnormalities. Atrial Myxomas: Introduction Most common primary cardiac tumors in adults. Location Often found in the left atrium. Types Sporadic. Familial: Carney Complex (Myxomas + skin lesions + Endocrinopathies). Clinical presentations Obstructive symptoms resembling mitral valve disease (e.g., dyspnea, fatigue). Embolic events: Risk of thrombus formation and systemic embolization. Constitutional symptoms: Fever, weight loss, fatigue due to cytokine secretion. Investigations Echocardiography, CT, MRI, Histopathology. Differential diagnoses: Tumor Type Characteristics Clinical Considerations Papillary Fibroelastoma Friable tumors with frond-like projections. Commonly found on cardiac valves. Can cause valve dysfunction and embolization. Generally resected. Rhabdomyoma Common in infants and children. Multiple in ~90% of cases. Associated with tuberous sclerosis (Option A ruled out) . May mimic valvular stenosis, CHF, or restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option C ruled out) . Hemangioma Generally small, often intramyocardial. May cause AV conduction (Option D ruled out) disturbances. Potential for sudden death if near AV nodes. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2025-2027

questions.question: During the cardiac cycle, the closing of the aortic valve takes place at the?
questions.explanation: corresponds to the second heart sound. Second heart sound (S2): Shorter, high-pitched ‘dub’ sound. Due to the closure of semilunar valves - Aortic and Pulmonary valves. Phases of Diastole: (duration: 0.5s) Phases Description Protodiastole Marks the earliest phase of diastole. Ventricular pressures drop more rapidly in a fully contracted state of ventricular musculature. Isovolumetric relaxation Ventricular musculature relaxes in an uniform pattern with both AV and semilunar valves closed. First rapid-filling phase Marks the opening of AV valves followed by rapid ventricular filling. Also known as the Passive filling phase (due to the difference in Atrial and ventricular pressures). Diastasis Pressures in the Atria and ventricles equal and ventricular filling rate declines rapidly and stops eventually. This momentary period of least ventricular filling is known as Diastasis. Last rapid filling Eject out the remaining blood left by active atrial contractions. Also known as the Active filling phase. Phases of systole (duration: 0.3s) Phases Description Isovolumetric Contraction Marks the onset of systole. Ventricles begin to contract with all valves closed , causing a rapid rise in intraventricular pressure without a change in volume. Rapid Ejection Phase Begins when ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary artery pressure , leading to opening of semilunar valves and rapid outflow of blood from the ventricles. Reduced Ejection Phase Ventricular contraction weakens, causing ejection to slow down ; although blood still flows out, the rate decreases as pressures in the ventricles and arteries begin to equalize.
